member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.DescriptiveStatistics
member.summary: Computes the basic statistics of data set. The class meets the NIST standard of accuracy for mean, variance, and standard deviation (the only statistics they provide exact values for) and exceeds them in increased accuracy mode.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: If set to true, increased accuracy mode used. Increased accuracy mode uses types for internal calculations.
member.remarks: Don't use increased accuracy for data sets containing large values (in absolute value). This may cause the calculations to overflow.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.AddVectorToScaledVector(`0[],`0,`0[])
member.summary: Adds a scaled vector to another: y += alpha*x.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the AXPY BLAS routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.ScaleArray(`0,`0[])
member.summary: Scales an array. Can be used to scale a vector and a matrix.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.AddArrays(`0[],`0[],`0[])
member.summary: Does a point wise add of two arrays z = x + y. This can be used to add vectors or matrices.
member.remarks: There is no equivalent BLAS routine, but many libraries provide optimized (parallel and/or vectorized) versions of this routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.SubtractArrays(`0[],`0[],`0[])
member.summary: Does a point wise subtraction of two arrays z = x - y. This can be used to subtract vectors or matrices.
member.remarks: There is no equivalent BLAS routine, but many libraries provide optimized (parallel and/or vectorized) versions of this routine.

member.param: The result of the point wise multiplication.
member.remarks: There is no equivalent BLAS routine, but many libraries provide optimized (parallel and/or vectorized) versions of this routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.MatrixMultiply(`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[])
member.summary: Multiples two matrices. result = x * y
member.param: The number of rows in the x matrix.
The number of columns in the x matrix.
The number of rows in the y matrix.
The number of columns in the y matrix.
Where to store the result of the multiplication.
member.remarks: This is a simplified version of the BLAS GEMM routine with alpha set to 1.0 and beta set to 0.0, and x and y are not transposed.

The number of columns in the matrix.
The value to scale the matrix.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.LUFactor(`0[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Computes the LU factorization of A.
member.param: An m by n matrix. The matrix is overwritten with the the LU factorization On exit.
On exit, it contains the pivot indices. The size of the array must be min(m,n).
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the GETRF LAPACK routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.LUInverse(`0[])
member.summary: Computes the inverse of matrix using LU factorization.
member.param: The N by N matrix to invert. Contains the inverse On exit.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the GETRF and GETRI LAPACK routines.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.LUInverseFactored(`0[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Computes the inverse of a previously factored matrix.
member.param: The LU factored N by N matrix. Contains the inverse On exit.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the GETRI LAPACK routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.LUInverse(`0[],`0[])
member.summary: Computes the inverse of matrix using LU factorization.
member.param: The N by N matrix to invert. Contains the inverse On exit.
The work array. The array must have a length of at least N, but should be N*blocksize. The blocksize is machine dependent. On exit, work[0] contains the optimal work size value.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the GETRF and GETRI LAPACK routines.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.LUInverseFactored(`0[],System.Int32[],`0[])
member.summary: Computes the inverse of a previously factored matrix.
member.param: The LU factored N by N matrix. Contains the inverse On exit.
The work array. The array must have a length of at least N, but should be N*blocksize. The blocksize is machine dependent. On exit, work[0] contains the optimal work size value.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the GETRI LAPACK routine.

member.summary: Computes the QR factorization of A.
member.param: On entry, it is the M by N A matrix to factor. On exit, it is overwritten with the R matrix of the QR factorization.
On exit, A M by M matrix that holds the Q matrix of the QR factorization.
member.remarks: This is similar to the GEQRF and ORGQR LAPACK routines.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.QRFactor(`0[],`0[],`0[])
member.summary: Computes the QR factorization of A.
member.param: On entry, it is the M by N A matrix to factor. On exit, it is overwritten with the R matrix of the QR factorization.
On exit, A M by M matrix that holds the Q matrix of the QR factorization.
The work array. The array must have a length of at least N, but should be N*blocksize. The blocksize is machine dependent. On exit, work[0] contains the optimal work size value.
member.remarks: This is similar to the GEQRF and ORGQR LAPACK routines.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.SinguarValueDecomposition(System.Boolean,`0[],`0[],`0[],`0[])
member.summary: Computes the singular value decomposition of A.
member.param: Compute the singular U and VT vectors or not.
On entry, the M by N matrix to decompose. On exit, A may be overwritten.
The singular values of A in ascending value.
If is true, on exit U contains the left singular vectors.
If is true, on exit VT contains the transposed right singular vectors.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the GESVD LAPACK routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.SingularValueDecomposition(System.Boolean,`0[],`0[],`0[],`0[],`0[])
member.summary: Computes the singular value decomposition of A.
member.param: Compute the singular U and VT vectors or not.
On entry, the M by N matrix to decompose. On exit, A may be overwritten.
The singular values of A in ascending value.
If is true, on exit U contains the left singular vectors.
If is true, on exit VT contains the transposed right singular vectors.

The work array. For real matrices, the work array should be at least Max(3*Min(M, N) + Max(M, N), 5*Min(M,N)). For complex matrices, 2*Min(M, N) + Max(M, N). On exit, work[0] contains the optimal work size value.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the GESVD LAPACK routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.SvdSolve(`0[],`0[],`0[],`0[],`0[],`0[])
member.summary: Solves A*X=B for X using the singular value decomposition of A.
member.param: On entry, the M by N matrix to decompose. On exit, A may be overwritten.
The singular values of A in ascending value.
On exit U contains the left singular vectors.
On exit VT contains the transposed right singular vectors.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ILinearAlgebraProvider`1.SvdSolve(`0[],`0[],`0[],`0[],`0[],`0[],`0[])
member.summary: Solves A*X=B for X using the singular value decomposition of A.
member.param: On entry, the M by N matrix to decompose. On exit, A may be overwritten.
The singular values of A in ascending value.
On exit U contains the left singular vectors.
On exit VT contains the transposed right singular vectors.

The work array. For real matrices, the work array should be at least Max(3*Min(M, N) + Max(M, N), 5*Min(M,N)). For complex matrices, 2*Min(M, N) + Max(M, N). On exit, work[0] contains the optimal work size value.

The left singular vectors returned by .
The right singular vectors returned by .

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Precision
member.summary: Utilities for working with floating point numbers.

remarks.para:
Useful links:
http://docs.sun.com/source/806-3568/ncg_goldberg.html#689 - What every computer scientist should know about floating-point arithmetic
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_epsilon - Gives the definition of machine epsilon

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.BinaryBaseNumber
member.summary: The base number for binary values

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.DoublePrecision
member.summary: The number of binary digits used to represent the binary number for a double precision floating point value. i.e. there are this many digits used to represent the actual number, where in a number as: 0.134556 * 10^5 the digits are 0.134556 and the exponent is 5.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.SinglePrecision
member.summary: The number of binary digits used to represent the binary number for a single precision floating point value. i.e. there are this many digits used to represent the actual number, where in a number as: 0.134556 * 10^5 the digits are 0.134556 and the exponent is 5.

member.summary: The maximum relative precision of a double

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision._singleMachinePrecision
member.summary: The maximum relative precision of a single

member.summary: The number of significant figures that a double-precision floating point has.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision._numberOfDecimalPlacesForFloats
member.summary: The number of significant figures that a single-precision floating point has.

member.summary: Value representing 10 * 2^(-52)

member.summary: Gets the equivalent long value for the given double value.
member.param: The double value which should be turned into a long value.
member.returns: The resulting long value.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.GetDirectionalLongFromDouble(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a 'directional' long value. This is a long value which acts the same as a double, e.g. a negative double value will return a negative double value starting at 0 and going more negative as the double value gets more negative.
member.returns: A long value which is roughly the equivalent of the double value.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.Increment(System.Double)
member.summary: Increments a floating point number to the next bigger number representable by the data type.
member.param: The value which needs to be incremented.
member.remarks: The incrementation step length depends on the provided value. Increment(double.MaxValue) will return positive infinity.
member.returns: The next larger floating point value.

member.summary: Increments a floating point number to the next bigger number representable by the data type.
member.param: The value which needs to be incremented.
How many times the number should be incremented.
member.remarks: The incrementation step length depends on the provided value. Increment(double.MaxValue) will return positive infinity.
member.returns: The next larger floating point value.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.Decrement(System.Double)
member.summary: Decrements a floating point number to the next smaller number representable by the data type.
member.param: The value which should be decremented.
member.remarks: The decrementation step length depends on the provided value. Decrement(double.MinValue) will return negative infinity.
member.returns: The next smaller floating point value.

member.summary: Decrements a floating point number to the next smaller number representable by the data type.
member.param: The value which should be decremented.
How many times the number should be decremented.
member.remarks: The decrementation step length depends on the provided value. Decrement(double.MinValue) will return negative infinity.
member.returns: The next smaller floating point value.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.CoerceZero(System.Double,System.Double)

member.summary: Forces small numbers near zero to zero.

member.summary: Returns the floating point number that will match the value with the tolerance on the maximum size (i.e. the result is always bigger than the value)

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.RangeOfMatchingNumbers(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int64@,System.Int64@)
member.summary: Determines the range of ulps that will match the specified value with the given tolerance.

The number of ULPS between the value and the value + relativeDifference.

Thrown if is double.PositiveInfinity or double.NegativeInfinity.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.NumbersBetween(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates the count of numbers between two double numbers
member.remarks: The second number is included in the number, thus two equal numbers evaluate to zero and two neighbor numbers evaluate to one. Therefore, what is returned is actually the count of numbers between plus 1.
member.returns: The number of floating point values between and .
member.exception: Thrown if is double.PositiveInfinity or double.NegativeInfinity.
Thrown if is double.PositiveInfinity or double.NegativeInfinity.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AlmostEqualInDecimalPlaces(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if they are equal to within the specified number of decimal places or not. If the numbers are very close to zero an absolute difference is compared, otherwise the relative difference is compared.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 10^(-numberOfDecimalPlaces). We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of the numbers, e.g. if == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.returns: if both doubles are equal to each other within the specified number of decimal places; otherwise .
member.exception: Thrown if is smaller than zero.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AlmostEqualInDecimalPlaces(System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two floats and determines if they are equal to within the specified number of decimal places or not. If the numbers are very close to zero an absolute difference is compared, otherwise the relative difference is compared.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 10^(-numberOfDecimalPlaces). We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of the numbers, e.g. if == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.returns: if both doubles are equal to each other within the specified number of decimal places; otherwise .
member.exception: Thrown if is smaller than zero.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AlmostEqualWithRelativeDecimalPlaces(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if they are equal to within the specified number of decimal places or not.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 10^(-numberOfDecimalPlaces). We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of the numbers, e.g. if == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.returns: if both doubles are equal to each other within the specified number of decimal places; otherwise .

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AlmostEqualWithAbsoluteDecimalPlaces(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if they are equal to within the specified number of decimal places or not, using the number of decimal places as an absolute measure.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 10^(-numberOfDecimalPlaces). We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of the numbers, e.g. if == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.returns: if both doubles are equal to each other within the specified number of decimal places; otherwise .

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AlmostEqual(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int64)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if they are equal to within the tolerance or not. Equality comparison is based on the binary representation.

remarks.para: Determines the 'number' of floating point numbers between two values (i.e. the number of discrete steps between the two numbers) and then checks if that is within the specified tolerance. So if a tolerance of 1 is passed then the result will be true only if the two numbers have the same binary representation OR if they are two adjacent numbers that only differ by one step.

The comparison method used is explained in http://www.cygnus-software.com/papers/comparingfloats/comparingfloats.htm . The article at http://www.extremeoptimization.com/resources/Articles/FPDotNetConceptsAndFormats.aspx explains how to transform the C code to .NET enabled code without using pointers and unsafe code.

member.param: The maximum number of floating point values between the two values. Must be 1 or larger.
member.returns: if both doubles are equal to each other within the specified tolerance; otherwise .
member.exception: Thrown if is smaller than one.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.IsLarger(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int64)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if the first value is larger than the second value to within the tolerance or not. Equality comparison is based on the binary representation.
member.param: The maximum number of floating point values for which the two values are considered equal. Must be 1 or larger.
member.returns: true if the first value is larger than the second value; otherwise false.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.IsLargerWithDecimalPlaces(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if the first value is larger than the second value to within the specified number of decimal places or not.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 10^(-numberOfDecimalPlaces). We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of the numbers, e.g. if == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.returns: true if the first value is larger than the second value; otherwise false.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.IsSmaller(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int64)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if the first value is smaller than the second value to within the tolerance or not. Equality comparison is based on the binary representation.
member.param: The maximum number of floating point values for which the two values are considered equal. Must be 1 or larger.
member.returns: true if the first value is smaller than the second value; otherwise false.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.IsSmallerWithDecimalPlaces(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if the first value is smaller than the second value to within the specified number of decimal places or not.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 10^(-numberOfDecimalPlaces). We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of thg. if == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.returns: true if the first value is smaller than the second value; otherwise false.

member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines which double is bigger.
member.param: The maximum error in terms of Units in Last Place (ulps), i.e. the maximum number of decimals that may be different. Must be 1 or larger.

item.description: is smaller than by more than the tolerance.
is equal to within the tolerance.
is bigger than by more than the tolerance.

member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines which double is bigger.

item.description: is smaller than by more than a magnitude equal to .
is equal to within a magnitude equal to .
is bigger than by more than a magnitude equal to .

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.DiscreteUniform
member.summary: The discrete uniform distribution is a distribution over integers. The distribution is parameterized by a lower and upper bound (both inclusive).

remarks.para: The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.

The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Weibull
member.summary: Implements the Weibull distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Weibull distribution.

remarks.para: The Weibull distribution is parametrized by a shape and scale parameter.
The distribution will use the by default. Users can get/set the random number generator by using the property.

The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Multinomial
member.summary: Implements the multinomial distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Multinomial distribution.

remarks.para: The distribution is parameterized by a vector of ratios: in other words, the parameter does not have to be normalized and sum to 1. The reason is that some vectors can't be exactly normalized to sum to 1 in floating point representation.
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.

The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.NevillePolynomialInterpolation
member.summary: Lagrange Polynomial Interpolation using Neville's Algorithm.

remarks.para: This algorithm supports differentiation, but doesn't support integration.
When working with equidistant or Chebyshev sample points it is recommended to use the barycentric algorithms specialized for these cases instead of this arbitrary Neville algorithm.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Beta
member.summary: Implements the Beta distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Beta distribution.

remarks.para: There are a few special cases for the parameterization of the Beta distribution. When both shape parameters are positive infinity, the Beta distribution degenerates to a point distribution at 0.5. When one of the shape parameters is positive infinity, the distribution degenerates to a point distribution at the positive infinity. When both shape parameters are 0.0, the Beta distribution degenerates to a Bernoulli distribution with parameter 0.5. When one shape parameter is 0.0, the distribution degenerates to a point distribution at the non-zero shape parameter.
The distribution will use the by default. Users can get/set the random number generator by using the property.

The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Complex
member.summary: Complex numbers class.

remarks.para: The class Complex provides all elementary operations on complex numbers. All the operators +, -, *, /, ==, != are defined in the canonical way. Additional complex trigonometric functions such as , ... are also provided. Note that the Complex structures has two special constant values and .
In order to avoid possible ambiguities resulting from a Complex(double, double) constructor, the static methods and are provided instead.
For mathematical details about complex numbers, please have a look at the Wikipedia

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.MetropolisSampler`1
member.summary:
Metropolis sampling produces samples from distribition P by sampling from a proposal distribution Q and accepting/rejecting based on the density of P. Metropolis sampling requires that the proposal distribution Q is symmetric. All densities are required to be in log space.
The Metropolis sampler is a stateful sampler. It keeps track of where it currently is in the domain of the distribution P.
member.typeparam: The type of samples this sampler produces.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.GlobalProposalSampler`1
member.summary: A method which samples datapoints from a proposal distribution. The implementation of this sampler is stateless: no variables are saved between two calls to Sample. This proposal is different from in that it doesn't take any parameters; it samples random variables from the whole domain.
member.typeparam: The type of the datapoints.
member.returns: A sample from the proposal distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.LocalProposalSampler`1
member.summary: A method which samples datapoints from a proposal distribution given an initial sample. The implementation of this sampler is stateless: no variables are saved between two calls to Sample. This proposal is different from in that it samples locally around an initial point. In other words, it makes a small local move rather than producing a global sample from the proposal.
member.typeparam: The type of the datapoints.
member.returns: A sample from the proposal distribution.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.GammaLn(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the logarithm of the Gamma function.
member.param: The argument of the gamma function.
member.returns: The logarithm of the gamma function.

remarks.para: This implementation of the computation of the gamma and logarithm of the gamma function follows the derivation in "An Analysis Of The Lanczos Gamma Approximation", Glendon Ralph Pugh, 2004. We use the implementation listed on p. 116 which achieves an accuracy of 16 floating point digits. Although 16 digit accuracy should be sufficient for double values, improving accuracy is possible (see p. 126 in Pugh).
Our unit tests suggest that the accuracy of the Gamma function is correct up to 14 floating point digits.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.Gamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the Gamma function.
member.param: The argument of the gamma function.
member.returns: The logarithm of the gamma function.

remarks.para: This implementation of the computation of the gamma and logarithm of the gamma function follows the derivation in "An Analysis Of The Lanczos Gamma Approximation", Glendon Ralph Pugh, 2004. We use the implementation listed on p. 116 which should achieve an accuracy of 16 floating point digits. Although 16 digit accuracy should be sufficient for double values, improving accuracy is possible (see p. 126 in Pugh).
Our unit tests suggest that the accuracy of the Gamma function is correct up to 13 floating point digits.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.Factorial(System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes the factorial function x -> x! of an integer number > 0. The function can represent all number up to 22! exactly, all numbers up to 170! using a double representation. All larger values will overflow.
member.returns: A value value! for value > 0
member.remarks: If you need to multiply or divide various such factorials, consider using the logarithmic version instead so you can add instead of multiply and subtract instead of divide, and then exponentiate the result using . This will also circumvent the problem that factorials become very large even for small parameters.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.FactorialLn(System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes the logarithmic factorial function x -> ln(x!) of an integer number > 0.
member.returns: A value value! for value > 0

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.MetropolisHastingsSampler`1
member.summary:
Metropolis-Hastings sampling produces samples from distribition P by sampling from a proposal distribution Q and accepting/rejecting based on the density of P. Metropolis-Hastings sampling doesn't require that the proposal distribution Q is symmetric in comparison to . It does need to be able to evaluate the proposal sampler's log density though. All densities are required to be in log space.
The Metropolis-Hastings sampler is a stateful sampler. It keeps track of where it currently is in the domain of the distribution P.
member.typeparam: The type of samples this sampler produces.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.MetropolisHastingsSampler`1.mPdfLnP
member.summary: Evaluates the log density function of the target distribution.

member.summary: Evaluates the log transition probability for the proposal distribution.

member.summary: A function which samples from a proposal distribution.

member.summary: The current location of the sampler.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.MetropolisHastingsSampler`1.mCurrentDensityLn
member.summary: The log density at the current location.

member.summary: The number of burn iterations between two samples.

member.summary: Constructs a new Metropolis-Hastings sampler using the default random number generator. The burn interval will be set to 0.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.LogNormal
member.summary: Implements the univariate Log-Normal distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Log-Normal distribution.

remarks.para: The distribution will use the by default. Users can get/set the random number generator by using the property.

The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Binomial
member.summary: Implements the binomial distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Binomial distribution.

remarks.para: The distribution is parameterized by a probability (between 0.0 and 1.0).
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.

The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Gamma
member.summary: Implements the univariate Gamma distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Gamma distribution.

remarks.para: The Gamma distribution is parametrized by a shape and inverse scale parameter. When we want to specify a Gamma distribution which is a point distribution we set the shape parameter to be the location of the point distribution and the inverse scale as positive infinity. The distribution with shape and inverse scale both zero is undefined.

Random number generation for the Gamma distribution is based on the algorithm in: "A Simple Method for Generating Gamma Variables" - Marsaglia & Tsang ACM Transactions on Mathematical Software, Vol. 26, No. 3, September 2000, Pages 363372.
The distribution will use the by default. Users can get/set the random number generator by using the property.

The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Complex32
member.summary: 32-bit Complex32 numbers class.

remarks.para: The class Complex32 provides all elementary operations on complex numbers. All the operators +, -, *, /, ==, != are defined in the canonical way. Additional complex trigonometric functions such as , ... are also provided. Note that the Complex32 structures has two special constant values and .
In order to avoid possible ambiguities resulting from a Complex32(float, float) constructor, the static methods and are provided instead.
For mathematical details about complex numbers, please have a look at the Wikipedia

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Complex32.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a complex number based on a string. The string can be in the following formats (without the quotes): 'n', 'ni', 'n +/- ni', 'ni +/- n', 'n,n', 'n,ni,' '(n,n)', or '(n,ni)', where n is a float.
member.returns: A complex number containing the value specified by the given string.

member.returns: A complex number containing the value specified by the given string.
member.param: An that supplies culture-specific formatting information.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Complex32.Infinity
member.summary: Gets a value representing the infinity value. This field is constant.
member.value: The infinity.
member.remarks: The semantic associated to this value is a Complex32 of infinite real and imaginary part. If you need more formal complex number handling (according to the Riemann Sphere and the extended complex plane C*, or using directed infinity) please check out the alternative Math.NET symbolics packages instead.
member.value: A value representing the infinity value.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ManagedLinearAlgebraProvider.AddVectorToScaledVector(System.Double[],System.Double,System.Double[])
member.summary: Adds a scaled vector to another: y += alpha*x.
member.remarks: This equivalent to the AXPY BLAS routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ManagedLinearAlgebraProvider.ScaleArray(System.Double,System.Double[])
member.summary: Scales an array. Can be used to scale a vector and a matrix.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the SCAL BLAS routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ManagedLinearAlgebraProvider.DotProduct(System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Computes the dot product of x and y.
member.returns: The dot product of x and y.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the DOT BLAS routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ManagedLinearAlgebraProvider.AddArrays(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Does a point wise add of two arrays z = x + y. This can be used to add vectors or matrices.
member.remarks: There is no equivalent BLAS routine, but many libraries provide optimized (parallel and/or vectorized) versions of this routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ManagedLinearAlgebraProvider.SubtractArrays(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Does a point wise subtraction of two arrays z = x - y. This can be used to subtract vectors or matrices.
member.remarks: There is no equivalent BLAS routine, but many libraries provide optimized (parallel and/or vectorized) versions of this routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ManagedLinearAlgebraProvider.PointWiseMultiplyArrays(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Does a point wise multiplication of two arrays z = x * y. This can be used to multiple elements of vectors or matrices.
member.param: The result of the point wise multiplication.
member.remarks: There is no equivalent BLAS routine, but many libraries provide optimized (parallel and/or vectorized) versions of this routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ManagedLinearAlgebraProvider.MatrixMultiply(System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary: Multiples two matrices. result = x * y
member.param: The number of rows in the x matrix.
The number of columns in the x matrix.
The number of rows in the y matrix.
The number of columns in the y matrix.
Where to store the result of the multiplication.
member.remarks: This is a simplified version of the BLAS GEMM routine with alpha set to 1.0 and beta set to 0.0, and x and y are not transposed.

member.summary: Multiplies two matrices and updates another with the result. c = alpha*op(a)*op(b) + beta*c
member.param: The number of rows in the matrix.
The number of columns in the matrix.
The number of rows in the matrix.
The number of columns in the matrix.
The value to scale the matrix.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ManagedLinearAlgebraProvider.AddArrays(MathNet.Numerics.Complex[],MathNet.Numerics.Complex[],MathNet.Numerics.Complex[])
member.summary: Does a point wise add of two arrays z = x + y. This can be used to add vectors or matrices.
member.remarks: There is no equivalent BLAS routine, but many libraries provide optimized (parallel and/or vectorized) versions of this routine.

member.summary: Does a point wise multiplication of two arrays z = x * y. This can be used to multiple elements of vectors or matrices.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Algorithms.LinearAlgebra.ManagedLinearAlgebraProvider.MatrixMultiply(MathNet.Numerics.Complex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,MathNet.Numerics.Complex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,MathNet.Numerics.Complex[])

The number of columns in the x matrix.
The number of rows in the y matrix.
The number of columns in the y matrix.

member.summary: Multiplies two matrices and updates another with the result. c = alpha*op(a)*op(b) + beta*c

The number of columns in the matrix.
The value to scale the matrix.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler
member.summary:
Slice sampling produces samples from distribition P by uniformly sampling from under the pdf of P using a technique described in "Slice Sampling", R. Neal, 2003. All densities are required to be in log space.
The slice sampler is a stateful sampler. It keeps track of where it currently is in the domain of the distribution P.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.mPdfLnP
member.summary: Evaluates the log density function of the target distribution.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.mCurrent
member.summary: The current location of the sampler.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.mCurrentDensityLn
member.summary: The log density at the current location.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.mBurnInterval
member.summary: The number of burn iterations between two samples.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.mScale
member.summary: The scale of the slice sampler.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.#ctor(System.Double,MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.DensityLn{System.Double},System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a new Slice sampler using the default random number generator. The burn interval will be set to 0.
member.param: The density of the distribution we want to sample from.
The scale factor of the slice sampler.
member.exception: When the scale of the slice sampler is not positive.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.#ctor(System.Double,MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.DensityLn{System.Double},System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a new slice sampler using the default random number generator. It will set the number of burnInterval iterations and run a burnInterval phase.
member.param: The density of the distribution we want to sample from.
The number of iterations in between returning samples.
The scale factor of the slice sampler.
member.exception: When the number of burnInterval iteration is negative.
When the scale of the slice sampler is not positive.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.Burn(System.Int32)
member.summary: This method runs the sampler for a number of iterations without returning a sample

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.Sample
member.summary: Returns a sample from the distribution P.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.BurnInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of iterations in between returning samples.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler.Scale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale of the slice sampler.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.RejectionSampler`1
member.summary: Rejection sampling produces samples from distribition P by sampling from a proposal distribution Q and accepting/rejecting based on the density of P and Q. The density of P and Q don't need to to be normalized, but we do need that for each x, P(x) < Q(x).
member.typeparam: The type of samples this sampler produces.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.RejectionSampler`1.mPdfP
member.summary: Evaluates the density function of the sampling distribution.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.RejectionSampler`1.mPdfQ
member.summary: Evaluates the density function of the proposal distribution.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.RejectionSampler`1.mProposal
member.summary: A function which samples from a proposal distribution.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.RejectionSampler`1.#ctor(MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.Density{`0},MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.Density{`0},MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.GlobalProposalSampler{`0})
member.summary: Constructs a new rejection sampler using the default random number generator.
member.param: The density of the distribution we want to sample from.
The density of the proposal distribution.
A method that samples from the proposal distribution.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.RejectionSampler`1.Sample
member.summary: Returns a sample from the distribution P.
member.exception: When the algorithms detects that the proposal distribution doesn't upper bound the target distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Categorical
member.summary: Implements the categorical distribution. For details about this distribution, see Wikipedia - Categorical distribution. This distribution is sometimes called the Discrete distribution.

remarks.para: The distribution is parameterized by a vector of ratios: in other words, the parameter does not have to be normalized and sum to 1. The reason is that some vectors can't be exactly normalized to sum to 1 in floating point representation.
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.

The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Categorical._p
member.summary: Stores the unnormalized categorical probabilities.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Categorical.#ctor(System.Double[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Categorical class.
member.param: An array of nonnegative ratios: this array does not need to be normalized as this is often impossible using floating point arithmetic.
member.exception: If any of the probabilities are negative or do not sum to one.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.Categorical.#ctor(MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Histogram)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Categorical class from a histogram . The distribution will not be automatically updated when the histogram changes. The categorical distribution will have one value for each bucket and a probability for that value proportional to the bucket count.
member.param: The histogram from which to create the categorical variable.
